Empty Product
In a monoid, the empty product is defined as the unit element, i.e., $\prod_{i=1}^{0} a_{i} := e$, where $e$ is the unit element.
Polynomial

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
Zero Divisor

An element a of a ring R is called a zero divisor if there exists an element b in R - {0} such that ab=0 or ba=0. Fields and skew fields do not admit any zero divisors, except for 0, the trivial zero divisor.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Least common multiple

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
Field of Fractions

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
Minimal Polynomial

The minimal polynomial of an element \\(\alpha\\) in a field extension is the monic polynomial of lowest degree in the base field that has \\(\alpha\\) as a root. It is a prime polynomial and generates the kernel of the evaluation homomorphism from the polynomial ring of the base field to the field generated by \\(\alpha\\). 
(Alt.2)
Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension and $\alpha \in L$ an element that is algebraic over $K$. The unique monic polynomial $f \in K[X]$ of smallest degree such that $f(\alpha)=0$ is called the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $K$.
Algebraic Element

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Extension Field

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
p-Sylow subgroup

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
Set
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: The minimal polynomial (ID: 6) is a specific type of polynomial that an algebraic element (ID: 7) satisfies, making it a specialization of the concept of an algebraic element.

The minimal polynomial (ID: 6) is a specific type of polynomial (ID: 1), defined as the monic polynomial of lowest degree that has a given element as a root, thus it is a specialization of the general concept of a polynomial.
